tips: Do not overlook the obvious
Check if indoor filters, coil, and blower wheel are clean
Verify the condenser is clean
Confirm the outdoor unit has adequate space for airflow
Confirm the indoor unit has adequate space for airflow
Determine if this is a new installation
Verify all service valves are open
Confirm the system was evacuated below 500 microns
For multi-zone units, verify wiring and linesets match the correct outdoor ports for each indoor unit (circuit is located at the bottom)
Linesets must be sized according to the indoor unit line sizes
Lineset adapters are used at the outdoor unit only
Verify if additional refrigerant charge was required per submittal or installation instructions
Power must be disconnected before performing resistance or sensor testing
Use needle-point probes for accurate readings
This error code will not be generated if the thermistor is simply out of range
Use the 15K thermistor chart to verify the sensor resistance matches ambient temperature
Refer to the Thermistor Temperature to Resistance Table
Indoor coil sensor and indoor ambient sensor share the same Molex connector at the board
Test the coil temperature sensor at the same time
The coil temperature sensor is a 20K thermistor
If initial resistance readings are acceptable, disconnect and visually inspect the sensors
Test sensors in ice water saturated with ice
At 32°F (0°C), resistance should match the thermistor chart
After warming the sensor in your hand, resistance should drop quickly
Intermittent failures may only appear during temperature change

steps.action: Replace indoor control board if sensors test good
tips: GREE uses negative temperature coefficient (NTC) thermistors
15K sensors are used for air or ambient temperature on indoor and outdoor units
20K sensors are used for coil and pipe temperature on indoor and outdoor units
The compressor discharge line uses a 50K sensor
Generic 15K, 20K, or 50K sensors may be used if they follow the same NTC resistance chart
Using approved generic sensors can allow first-trip repair
All splices must follow best practices and be moisture-proof
